column1: Current percentage of population that has or has had COVID
column4: Number of COVID cases in 2020 divided by total population

column1: Number of months until country expects to achieve herd immunity
column3: Original study in June 2020:  5-6 months - more likely at least 1 year
column4: Length of community spread (in months). After this period, between 40% and 70% of the population will have been infected (corresponds to herd immunity required for R0 between 1.6 and 3.6

column1: Proportion of SARS-CoV2 infected population at end of risk period
column4:
Herd immunity calculated based on R0:
=1 - 1/R0
Expected number of cases directly generated by one case in a population where all individuals are susceptible to infection

column1: Increased risk of infection for inpatient stay vs. ambulatory visit (1 day stay vs. 1 outpatient visit)
column4: Higher risk of getting infected  due to a) longer stay in a potentially contagious environment, b) contacts with more health care providers,
Assumption that if either child or caretaker gets infected they will infect a large percentage of other household members, owing to the high secondary attack rates observed for family gatherings
